JUDGES: David Thór Björgvinsson;Ján Šikuta;Lech Garlicki;Mihai Poalelungi;Nicolas Bratza;Päivi Hirvelä
TEXT: The applicant , PERSON , is a NORP national who was born in DATE and lives in PERSON . He was represented before the Court by Mr PERSON , a lawyer practising in GPE . ORG ( “ the Government ” ) were represented by their Agent , Mr PERSON of ORG .
The facts of the case , as submitted by the parties , may be summarised as follows .
On DATE the applicant was placed in pre - trial detention in the course of criminal proceedings against him .

On DATE a bill of indictment was filed with ORG against QUANTITY persons including the applicant . After the bill of indictment had been filed , PERSON , the applicant 's commonlaw wife , was allowed to visit him in prison .
On DATE PERSON applied to be allowed to visit the applicant in prison . On DATE the court refused her request .

On DATE the applicant 's lawyer asked the court to allow the applicant to have prison visits from PERSON On DATE ORG refused the request and informed the applicant that at this stage of the proceedings he could not receive prison visits . The refusal was motivated by the need to secure the proper conduct of the proceedings . The proceedings concerned several co - accused and the process of gathering evidence had not been finished . Even though PERSON was not a witness in the proceedings it was not possible to allow her to visit the applicant , at least until the key witnesses in the proceedings had been heard .

On DATE the applicant 's lawyer complained to ORG and to the Ombudsman . He stressed that the applicant was being refused all prison visits and that ORG had not specified the duration of this prohibition .
On DATE , on the applicant 's appeal , ORG informed him that ORG was competent to decide on prison visits for the applicant .
PERSON 's further applications for permission to visit the applicant in prison of DATE , DATE , DATE and DATE were dismissed .

On DATE the ORG informed the applicant that the refusal of family visits in prison was due to the complicated nature of the proceedings and the fact that several co - accused were involved . It would further appear that as soon as all the witnesses in the proceedings had been heard , the applicant would be allowed prison visits .
At the hearing held on DATE the court allowed PERSON 's motion and agreed that she could visit the applicant in prison . The applicant states that she visited him on DATE .
Subsequently , PERSON was allowed to visit the applicant on numerous occasions .
On DATE ORG convicted the applicant as charged . On DATE the ORG quashed the firstinstance judgment and remitted the case .
The applicant was released on bail on DATE .
The proceedings are pending before the court of first - instance .
The relevant domestic law and practice concerning detainees ' right to receive visitors in remand centres are stated in the ORG 's judgment in the case of ORG v. GPE , no . CARDINAL , LAW , DATE .
